query: SELECT DISTINCT observations.id FROM `observations` ORDER BY observations.id ASC

results.notes:
On Quercus alba. This is a second observation of the same fungus showing a different stage than in the post at http://mushroomobserver.org/231456. The earlier observation was of one log section (Log Section 1) from two dates: 2015-04-03 and 2016-02-16. I went back with two friends on 2016-02-21 and photographed more of the Log Section 1 as well the adjacent section from the same tree (Log Section 2) in which the fungus was at a different stage than Log Section 1.

Log Section 1: Pore surface reddish-brown and not bruising, even the pore surfaces that were soft to the touch (not hardened by exposure to outside environment). Pore surface extended the length of the 2 m log, and wrapped under the log approximately 75 cm wide. The pore surface was reddish brown on 2015-04-03 as well as currently.

Log Section 2: Pore surface whitish and readily bruising. Detail photos included of raised pore sections (3 cm) that contact the woody surface below the pore surface. The raised pore sections contact the woody surface below — they may function like “spacers.”

results.notes:
Growing on eucalyptus debris (cones, leaves, bark or wood pieces).

Odor “fungal”, rather strong, neither farinaceous nor unpleasant.

Spores 8-9 × 5.5-6, hyaline, inamyloid. Couldn’t produce a visible spore print.

Flesh very tin, pileipellis cellular. Clamps in all tissues. Cystidia abundant.

The presence of cystidia eliminates Dermoloma (according to books) and leaves me clueless.

results.notes:
Cluster of mushrooms spread over an approximately 9 sq. meters under mixed hardwood/pine forest; growing in soil some in close proximity to tree roots.
Cap, 8 to 12 cm diameter, depressed; margin lobed and wavy; color medium brown progressing to cream/light brown at the margin with some scaling on one older cap; surface dull.
Flesh thick, corky; tan colored with some deeper brown lines in flesh; staining olive with 3% KOH.
Teeth approximately 4-5 mm long, 0.5 mm wide; slightly decurrent; gray in color.
Stem. Approximately 2 cm long and wide; tapering from apex to base; same color as center of cap.
Odor. Not distinctive.
Thinking Bankera fuligineoalba

Pileus: Pale yellow, no volval remnants, convex, small – 4 cm diameter.

Gills: Free, pale yellow, close.

Stipe: Pale yellow. Persistent skirt-like ring. Dark bruising visible on the ring. No measurement.

Base: Abrupt, bulbous. ~3 3/4 cm width, ~2 1/2 cm length.

Odor: None detected.

Bruising: Prior dark bruising visible, but I did not cut into the mushroom.

Spore Print: None taken.

Habitat: Pine flatwoods with few trees nearby (pines and the rare oak tree scattered around); many shrubs. Sugar sand. South-Central Florida, late February.

results.notes:
Pileus: Pink toned, pallid, no volval remnants. 3 1/4 cm diameter.

Gills: Free, possible prior dark bruising on the edges. Yellow-pink toned, pale. Close.

Stalk: 7 3/4 cm long (entire mushroom). Delicate, pallid, pink toned. More color above ring than below it. Ring-zone present, think it was skirt-like (most of it is gone).

Base: Bulbous. Pink toned. Very lightly rooting. 2 cm length, 1 3/4 cm width.

Spore Print: None taken.

Odor: Not detected.

Habitat: Pine flatwoods, not many trees nearby (pines, occasional oak) – many shrubs. South-central Florida. Growing in sugar sand.

results.notes:
Growing scattered around an Oak.
Caps up to 10.5cm across.
Most fbs were leggy and difficult to extract from ground without losing portions of the volva and base.
Spore print was white and spores amyloid.
Spores were quite variable, ellipsoid to pear-shaped.
Spores ~ 9.0-13.0 X 6.5-9.4 microns.
Q(range) = 1.24-1.49(1.64)
Q(avg) = 1.37 n=23
KOH on cap turned yellow.
These appear to the “salmon” colored version of Amanita ocreata.
Also, the spores on some of them curiously shaped but surprisingly the average size and Q values are quite close to normal per RET’s website.

results.notes: This mushroom was one of 4 or 5 A. ocreata collected that were growing together in a small group of about a dozen. Some were typical in appearance. All of the mushrooms shared the same cap coloration, and partial veil. Most of the mushrooms had narrow bases and solid stems, however this was the only specimen whose stem was almost completely hollow, which is a first in my experience. This combined with the narrow or unenlarged base gave the stem a very similar appearance to that of A. velosa. Some of the photos show this mushroom with A. velosa or other ocreata for comparison. The dried material is stored at Herbarium Rooseveltensis Amanitarum

results.notes:
Cap: Medium brown, umbonate, darker in center, wrinkled, flesh moist, 10 cm diameter.

Gills: Beige, attached, short gills present, distant.

Stipe: Brittle (snaps easily), moist flesh, off white, vertically striated, 18 1/2 cm long.

Base: I was unable to find any base or root structure, although it seems to have been ripped or eaten around that area. Amazingly enough, it was still standing in the dirt.

Spore print: White

Odor: Strong and mushroomy.

Habitat: I believe it was growing on rotted wood under the soil. Connecticut, fall, hardwood/conifer forest.

Spores: 15-17 microns in length. ~11 microns width. Mounted in Lugol’s dilute iodine solution. Lemon shaped.
results.location_name: Ledyard, Connecticut, USA

results.notes:
IN PROGRESS

Habitat -wooded area above glade. Growing on a rotting log that is part of a felled massive Oak, looks to be Southern Red Oak. All the wood was very decayed but despite being there for many years, there are still massive logs around the stump of the old oak.

Chemical Tests – none done

Smell – almost no smell
Taste – did not

Spore Print – white, heavy deposit
Spore photos – dimensions – TBD

Cap – specimens vary in size from a 1 cm button (veil intact) to a large mature – flattened cap 7-8 inches across. Cap context on largest cap was dense ( ~ 1 cm thick), appeared to flash to yellow as I cut it. I could not be sure if the cap context was changing color but I did several cuts and my impression was that it instantly flashed to yellow when I cut it. Covered by scales that are most dense near the center an lifting toward edges. Top is a golden color which whitens as it ages to ivory.

Gills – serrated – edges darkening – see images. Ivory color, attached – decurrent
Stipe – up to 2 cm thick. Dense, not quite tough as I could cleanly cut through it but I had to use a little force to cut through.

Stipe – thick dense up to 2 cm thick – covered tiny scales similar to cap

Habitat: light, mixed woodland Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica dominant; slightly inclined mountain slope, south aspect; calcareous, skeletal ground; half shade, quite humid place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6 – 8 deg C, elevation 715 m (2.350 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: mostly debarked places of a heavily decayed, still standing trunk of Fagus sylvatica.

Place: Vrsnik valley, below ‘Na skali’ settlement, above Pod Vršičem place, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Growing on several places of a still standing trunk of large Fagus sylvatica. Ascomata confluent into patches up to 25 × 10 cm, with bumps from 3 to 10(15) mm in diameter, 2 to 6(10) mm thick, perithecia about 1 mm in diameter; very brittle, so it can’t be cut even not with a sharp surgical knife without breaking it into pieces; no smell; SP none, spores found within crashed perithecia; these were rather old sporocarps.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Vrsnik valley region, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
The site of my observations this day is located at approximately 680m above the sea level and not far from the higher level at the north part of this big location (~750 m). The rocks are granitic and the vegetation is constituted mainly by chestnuts and oaks. I think this is a very selective habitat, because here one can see plenty of specimens of certain species of the “Lobarion community” like, for instance, Degelia plumbea, Lobaria scrobiculata, Pannaria rubiginosa, Nephroma laevigatum, just to cite a few, but one is (I was) unable to see the other species of the same genus that exist at this big location.
My first reports at this place this date are of other species existing here, which are not so common for me or even unknown. This is the case of this observation, whose specimens I think to belong to the genus Hypotrachina, but the species is not so easy for me. The most salient features are the small lobes and the dark green soredia, contrary to the usual grey in some of the species already observed. Of course, this can be consequence of the local conditions, like exposition, because the specimens grew over the stones of a fence separating different properties. These specimens are similar to other set observed here, to be considered at another observation (observation 233816), and can even be of the same species, in which case H. britannica is a clear candidate.
results.location_name: Serra de São Mamede, Portugal

results.notes:
See observation 233815.
Very common on bark here are the Leptogium with green-black rounded lobes much swollen, due to wet, and conspicously isidiate. It very hard for me to decide between L. brebissonii and L. coralloideum in most of the cases. As is known these two species are ver similar and the isidia, mostly appearing along the ridges of the lobes, can be coralloid in both species, though more developed in the latter. I have a gallery of photos with different specimens and chose two sets with (I think) the two species cited above, but many intermediate forms exist.
This observation consist of specimens that I think to be L. brebissonii.

results.notes: Upper surface is olive-brown and olive when wet, dark brown up to grayish-light brown when dry. It has scattered and mainly radian orientation pustules (up to abundand). Bottom surface is dark brown and blackish up to light brown to the edges; the surface structure is shagreene up to fine papuillary. Apothecia are rounded and sessile; disk for single apothecia is flat or some sunken and black (complex crowded disk apothecia are possible); dick and its edge are often micro bumpy and occursinally with central knob). Apothecia are located irregular, but closer to margin. Margin is wavy and curved down when wet. Isidia are rare and scale-like. There are two similar other Lasallia species in Kazakhstan (L. papulosa is twice bigger and L. pensylvanica has no isidia according the guide book).

results.notes:
Code: Bot_934/2016_IMG9652

Habitat: light, mixed woodland Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica dominant; almost flat terrain; calcareous, skeletal ground; half shade, quite humid place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6 – 8 deg C, elevation 625 m (2.050 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: highly disintegrated, moss and lichen covered (most probably) Fagus sylvatica trunk.

Place: Vrsnik valley, below ‘Na skali’ settlement, ‘Pod Vršičem’ place, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Pilei effuse-reflexed and confluent, individual up to 6 cm wide and up to 2.3 cm off the substratum, from 1 to 2 mm thin, hymenium up to 0.5 thick, context with a dark, thin line under the tomentum; smell distinct, like radish or chemicals, taste unpleasant, on chemicals; SP abundant, whitish-yellowish-beige, between oac900 and oac851.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes: Specimens fruiting at first on top as resupinate growth on the substrate, then forming small, shelf-like fruit bodies/folded over caps extending out from the sides of a fallen, soggy hardwood log at the edge of a small stream. Area recently underwater. Fruit bodies thick, gelatinous, flexible, rubbery/tough with age. Upper surface has adpressed hairs (likely due to being underwater for a period of time). Fertile surface: a wrinkled/folded network of cross-veined forks and ridges giving the illusion of pores. I want to say Phlebia tremellosa because of the meruloid-hydnoid fertile surface, but due to environmental conditions it does not have the typical “fluffy” cap surface and margins one normally expects. Photo collage (last image) shows close-up sections of the fertile surfaces from several of these specimens.

on exposed face of sandstone boulder; sandstone outcrop in open pinyon-juniper forest on ridge over very sandy noncalcareous soil; ridge beyond end of FR 1144, ca. 2 miles west of entrance to Maze District of Canyonlands National Park

scattered among Staurothele areolata, subsquamulose to angular-areolate pale gray areoles, surface gray from coarsely wwrinkled phenocortex (visible as hyaline rugae on top of brown-colored true cortex in section), perithecia up to ~0.2mm wide immersed except for black small disk around apex, exciple dark brown and thick at apex and hyaline throughout the rest becoming thin and brown in age, involucrellum totally absent, spores 8 per ascus broadly ellipsoid ~12-13×8-10um, conidia straight oblong to ellipsoid ~5-7×1-1.5um
results.location_name: French Spring Canyon, Wayne Co., Utah, USA

results.notes: A redlisted and poorly understood species in Yugra, which is probably way more common than we think. I keep finding more and more of it in old rich taiga forests. Formerly known as Lentinus martianoffianus and Lentinus pilososquamulosus (there’s a pending taxonomic disaster here because the new genus Lignomyces was described independently based on “unidentified” specimens). In our area it grows on birch.

Apothecia large, globose, with black disk and white pruinose rim; disk is not pruinose.

I tried hard to get any K+ reaction and nothing. Will update with conidia and other micro details. Specimen looks a lot like Aspicilia cinerea photo on
http://www.lichensmaritimes.org/...
except that this species should be K+R on thallus and medulla. [Edit: spores are slightly too large for A. cinerea.]

Otherwise it keys ok to Aspicilia caesiocinerea if we assume Asci with 8 spores, and short conidia. [EDIT: A. caesiocinerea is K-]

results.notes:
Code: Bot_401/2009_DSC6837

Habitat: light primary wood on former pastures in a group of Betula pendula, slightly inclined mountain slope, southwest aspect; cretaceous clastic rock (flysh) bedrock; in half shade, quite humid place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 500 m (1.650 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead standing and fallen trunks of Betula pendula as well as rarely on stumps.

Place: Bovec basin, at the foot of Mt. Svinjak, 1.965 m (6.447 feet), above Kal-Koritnica village, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Many fruitbodies were present at the place of this observation. The largest one had 30 cm across.

Nikon D70 /AF-S Nikkor 18-70mm/f3.5-4.5G ED
